title: Physics Concepts as Indicative Framework for Modelling Systems of Economy

2. Introduction
The state (situation, position) of the Economy can be described by e.g. Assets, Liabilities, Costs, Earnings, Productivity, etc.. The Economy changes through time from a state \(r_{init}=\) “start” to a state \(r=\) “final”. For the state to change (e.g. GDP growth), work is applied by processing limited resources (e.g. raw materials and minerals), constrained capital, and labor capacity.
Human kind has evolved also by “copying” from nature. Learning from nature, how can “work” be modelled?
The state (position) \(r\) shall be modelled by the work \(W\) applied for the change (dispacement): \(r = \int A = \int \int W\)





3. Method, Elements, Scope & Approach
\[\begin{split} &
\pm W = \partial A = \partial(E \cdot t) = \partial(p ⋅ r)   \\&
\stackrel{Geometrical}{=} F \cdot r = mr \cdot a = I ⋅ \frac{v}{t} =  \frac{p}{t} ⋅ tv = Ft \cdot v =  pv = mv^2 \\&
\stackrel{Analytical}{=} \mathcal{L} + \mathcal{H} = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + (\mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}) = (\mathcal{K} - (\mathcal{V} + \mathcal{Z})) + (\mathcal{K} + \mathcal{U}) = (\mathcal{K} - \mathcal{U}) + E   \\&
\stackrel{ElectroMagnetic}{=}  \left( \frac{1}{2}mv^2 - q(\Phi - \vec{\mathcal{A}} \cdot \vec{v}) \right) + \left( \frac{1}{2} \frac{1}{m} (\vec{p} - q\vec{\mathcal{A}})^2 + q\Phi \right)   \\&
\stackrel{Relativistic}{=} \frac{v}{c} \sqrt{E^2 - (mc^2)^2}   \\&
\stackrel{ThermoStatistical}{=} ΔY - ΔH = \Delta(T \cdot \Delta S - P \cdot \Delta V) - \Delta(T\cdot S) \\&
= PV^{\iota} = T \cdot V^{\frac{f+2}{f}} = T \cdot V^{(\frac{c_P}{c_V}-1)} = T \cdot V^{\kappa-1} = T \cdot l \cdot g_0 = T \cdot n \cdot b_0 = T \cdot m \cdot c_0    \\&
\stackrel{Quantistic}{=} ħ\mathcal{k} \cdot ω = ℎν\mathcal{k} = E\mathcal{k}    \\&
\end{split}\]

Macro-Economy: Goods Market (Production, Lager), Capital Market (Savings, Investments), Labor Market (Employment, Population Structure), Price vs. Value, Demand vs. Supply, Access to Resources, Trade & International Contracts

\\&
